title: 3d keen movie (for sure this time)
content:
allright people, since i have not heard anything from duke4e in a long time(?), i have started on the little cg intro movie.

i'm currently working on the interia of Billy's backyard house
(the research desk atm)

i will post an image as soon as i can [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img] (maby even today)

everybody take care!

title: Re: update again
content:
Ungodly cool. I just can't say anything else. Maybe you could make that torus-like antenne a bit more metallic it looks like plastic a bit, but this is minimal. This makes my modelling skills look like a pile of garbage.
------------------------------------------------------
Keep in mind, I'm not an artist.

When the master said "Kaputt!", the end of the Great War could be felt.

title: Pure Keenishness...
content:
This is right up there on the Classmeter alongside KeenX/Null and iKeen... I never thought we'd see Keen('s stuff) in such photorealistic detail. Well done. Gonna be mind-blowing to see this stuff animated.[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-drool.gif[/img]

>Commander SpeenCave assectatorem Ductoris Alacris

title: Repeat:
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]i dont think this movie will ever get done. no offence or anything, but u have to admit, its a shait load of work, even for a pro. how long is this movie going to be? what resolution?[hr][/quote]

well, it IS a shitload of work. don't be such a pessimist.
there is no guarantee that this movie will be finished but since i'm an oldtime Keen fan and really like to practice my 3dskills i will work as long as i can with this.

and as i said in the previous posts, i'm getting help by a couple of guys. one has offered me to render this movie on a renderfarm.
(quite a fast one too, 128 computers each with eight 64bit 2ghz cpus and 16gb ram) so it might render this movie in a flash [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

title: What program?
content: Alright, what 3D program are you doing this in? This thing is lookin' way past cool. I still want to see how an actual character is in this environment, but it's looking great![url=http://www.screenhog.com]www.screenhog.com[/url]

title: re: character animation
content:
Character animation is an industry weakpoint in the current timeframe of video games... Games that I've seen with good animation are few and far between. The only one that's sparked me as consistently good was Kingdom Hearts, and that's because it had Disney fuelling it. I really honestly wish you the best of luck with the animating of Keen, DSL... it's tough to get stuff to look good. I'm sure Ilsoap's got a load of tips for making stuff look good for less work (like avoiding showing the character's legs while they're moving across a scene, or having a character speak with his back turned to the camera so you just have to animate the head motion, not the mouth, etc.)

--Xky

title: Re: re: character animation
content:
Avoiding showing the character's legs in 2D might be less work, but in 3D, it's still very helpful to animate the legs anyways, simply so that you know where the body should be. You don't have to animate the legs well if you can't see them, but animate them well enough that you know where the body should be. In most action, the thrust of the body comes from the hips, and to know how high the hips are off the ground, you need to still know where the feet should be.

The key to making lip sync work isn't in whether or not the character is pointing in your direction, it's in the body language. What you're saying is 50% determined by how you act. In fact, many animators, when starting a lip sync scene, perfect the body motion first before touching the face -- that's a must in 2D animation, actually. When I'm doing 3D lip-sync animation, I usually do the face first, but I still focus on the body in the long run.

Note to self: talking about animation makes me want to do some. Remind me of this the next time I'm in an animation slump.[url=http://www.screenhog.com]www.screenhog.com[/url]

title: Re: re: character animation
content:
Renderfarms, eh? I've always wanted to hack one of those whilst it was in downtime, so I could run DOSBox faster [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-mortlol.gif[/img]
If Keen eats all that sugar, why doesn't he get a coronary?
goto [url=http://www.toxicsheep.com]www.toxicsheep.com[/url] to see my site!

title: Re: re: character animation
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]Character animation is an industry weakpoint in the current timeframe of video games... Games that I've seen with good animation are few and far between. The only one that's sparked me as consistently good was Kingdom Hearts, and that's because it had Disney fuelling it. I really honestly wish you the best of luck with the animating of Keen, DSL... it's tough to get stuff to look good. I'm sure Ilsoap's got a load of tips for making stuff look good for less work (like avoiding showing the character's legs while they're moving across a scene, or having a character speak with his back turned to the camera so you just have to animate the head motion, not the mouth, etc.)[hr][/quote]

Thanks but allready know the trix to simplify the work.
(not my first cgmovie you know) also i have gone through movie making school and i dare to say i know pretty much all the things i need to make good, expressive characters.
I think i would go for Pixarish character movements.
You know, fast and exaggerated movements. Stuff like that is easier to animate than real human motion.


About the lipsync thingy...
Maby i should make a previz (roughly rendered) version of the film (no animated lips) with subtitles for the lines and you guys could help me with the voices?

btw, neat animations Ilsoap [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]

title: Re: Stunning.
content:
Before there wasn't anything to compare the head against.
Now there's the helmet looking big, making the head look smaller.
Once you get to the body, you can make that relatively small again, since younger children have quite a large head for their size.
Anyway, looking good!

What is everybody comparing it against anyway?
The in-game sprites are really too tiny to give a very good impression of what Keen looks like, even in the later Keen games, which I'm mostly referring to.
(Although with the tiny amount of people I do think they did a great job on getting the look.)
The ending sequences and finished-level sequences have some slightly larger Keen heads, but still pretty small.

Only the title screens, and especially box art actually gives a pretty nicely sized head/face to look at.
See the logo at the top of this board too, of course.
Even then, he's a relatively simple character, like a flat-shaded egg with a couple of eyes and eyebrows, a little, yet bulbous nose, a big mouth, some freckles and that's about it.
In other words, it's pretty hard to make something that actually looks like Keen, in my opinion.Retodon8
You live, you die, you are remembered, you are forgotten.

title: *ponders*
content:
[hr]Retodon8 What is everybody comparing it against anyway?
[hr]I have no idea. Just as soon as I looked at the image it jumped out at me as "KEEN!" I compared it with the banner at the top afterward, but I couldn't work out exactly why it looks so right. Maybe it's just the helmet...

Maybe if you posted another image with the [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-offended.gif[/img] expression we'd be able to make a better comparison.Cave assectatorem Ductoris Alacris

title: Re: hey
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]did z-1 do that, too?[hr][/quote]
I did what? [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img] What I've linked is box modelling too. The main idea is to create a box or any basic object and start from there. It's nothing more. You can extrude the faces, create new edges etc. from that afterwards.

I used to creating 3D models but I never was quiet good in it so I gave up. There's only a few images I've finished. But I read the forums and tutorials at [url=http://www.3dtotal.com]3dtotal[/url] often. It's a nice source of information to begin with.

title: Re: lol
content:
Star Wars Episodes IV, V, and VI ROCK! Three of my all-time favorite movies! The visuals of Star Wars Episodes I & II are the only redeeming qualities of said movies. Episode I was a mediocre movie by itself, but George Lucas completely threw his reputation away with the incredibly AWFUL Episode II. Hopefully Episode III will be better...[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-dexter.gif[/img]

But I'm getting off-topic. I think a castle modeled like the ones on the second trilogy of SW would look good. The only image I can form of the Keen4 opening castle is how it was seen in Ilsoap's Rule of a Yorp's Supper, surrounded by desert with a few trees and cliffs in the distance, with the castle itself being kind of orangey brick like the Keen4 pyramids. I still think that game is genius...

But do whatever you want to DSL! We already trust you enough in making things look Keenish to let you go wild! [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]

title: CK:CM
content:
A Star Wars inspired city is a safe bet. We came to the same conclusion over at K:M for the Community Mod project, with a bit of a Tyrian spin on it.

[hr]KeenRush Yes, and the Oracle is a machine. I have always imagined that place as something big city, where the building touch the clouds, and Oracle is on a roof of some of them. (Like that one city in for example Star Wars: Episode 1!)
[hr]

[hr]Yowza As for the Oracle - I always thought of it as being on a Coruscant-ish city aswell. Maybe we could have it set a little less west.. Perhaps where the 'civilised' part of Gnosticus IV ends, and where the Shadowlands begin.
[hr]

[hr]Lemur A Gnosticene city would also be a fun level, especially if it were floating. It could be a bunch of buildings over a pit (if that's possible). That's a bit premature for this planning phase, so I'll hold the thought.
[hr]

[hr]Yowza Although, I was thinking of something more like Coruscant from Star Wars... But with most of the buildings on floating rocks. Basically, the earlier levels would be closer to the ground (or water), and the levels would consist of being in the buildings, and jumping between them. Gradually, you would get higher up in the buildings, and possibly even revisit ones you've already been too (but way higher up).
[hr]

[hr]ScizorCT I was thinking more along the lines of Miragia, from Commander Keen, but floating. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]

*ducks flying bricks*
[hr]

[hr]Me some of the stuff found in Tyrian could make for the basis of some interesting CKCM ideas...

[...] Gravitium ore is very similar to the stuff found on Gnosticene. It fits perfectly into the storyline of both Keen4 and the CKCM.
[hr]

[hr]ScizorCT Let's say that on Gnosticus IV, a combination of odd tectonic forces and gravitational pull have made possible the existence of an element that is capable of quite a bit more than your average rock. Through a bit of research, the Gnosticines discovered that it could be used to A. Make stuff float, and B. Fiddle with time. The first discovery of this element was when the Lifewater Oasis first appeared: A mineral spring bubbling up from the depths of the planet, which may or may not have anything to do with the Ancients being immortal, but that's beside the point. Mining operations later found more of it, although under incredible pressure and uncomfortably close to large pockets of magma. Unfortuately, a few foolhardy miners blasted through to some magma, which resulted in the entire operation being shut down. The Chasm of Chills and Cave of Descendants can be seen as the remnants of the earlier mining. Later operations were further east, preferably as far from the Shadowlands as possible. What was finally mined of the material was transported to the city and mostly used to make it float, thus defending it from most of the monsters on the planet.
[hr]

[hr]Lemur Maybe the city could be divided into multiple districs or something that are connected by water tunnels that dip down under water.
[hr]

[hr]ScizorCT The more I've thought about it, the more it seems like that idea fits into the Shadowlands though. Out by the Lifewater Oasis are Sand Yego and Miragia. Why? Perhaps Sand Yego was once the stockhold for the mined ore before being shipped elsewhere. It seems like Miragia is an abandoned test site for the ore, really. Some really funky stuff occurs there with no real reason why, and the scenery there is found no where else in the Shadowlands. Perhaps the Wetsuit was once used to explore the Oasis? At any rate, I'd be willing to wager that Miragia would be a good basis for the city graphics of Ep. 3. Still, other locations like the Perilous Pit (looks as much like a mineshaft as anything I've seen) and the Isle of Tar (deep with huge tar pits. Sound like a failed shaft to you?) just seem logical.
[hr]

Well, there's some food for thought. It'll be awesome to see this stuff in full 3D.Cave assectatorem Ductoris Alacris

JimSoft Lair
http://jimsoft.spatang.com/
